fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • Because of an editing error, an article about a surge in cases of the tick-borne illness Lyme disease this summer said that many GPs and hospital staff “have never heard of the disease”. What the author of the article wrote was that many GPs and hospital staff have not encountered the disease (Concern over big rise in cases of Lyme disease, 5 December, page 18). • In a piece about the closure of Britain’s last deep coalmine, Kellingley colliery in North Yorkshire (The end of the mine, 5 December, page 34), we referred to a “demonstration planned for 19 December”. The organisers of the event have asked us to clarify that it is a farewell march for the miners, their families and supporters, not a demonstration. • Our obituary of the theatre and opera director Luc Bondy (5 December, page 54) referred to his 1996 production of Verdi’s Don Carlos at Covent Garden and said the conductor was Antonio Pappano. It was Bernard Haitink. • A picture of choirboys skating on Winchester Cathedral’s ice rink was headlined “Cathedral’s sopranos on skates” (9 December, page 21). A former member of the choir has written to assure us that the skating boys are not sopranos but trebles (although young males who sing in the soprano range are sometimes known as “boy sopranos”). • Other recently corrected articles include: $100bn?
